# John Snow, pioneering anesthesiologist
"He sits alone in his cluttered flat, frogs croaking around him, illuminated only by candlelight. After a few minutes tinkering...he fastens the mouthpiece over his face and releases the gas. Within seconds, his head hits the desk. Then minutes later, he wakes, consults his watch through blurre vision. He reaches for his pen, and starts recording the data."
# Some Discussion Questions >- What struck you most about the introductory chapters? Specific passages? >- What - if any - parallels do you potentially see to the present day? >- Anything confusing? # A quote I love from *The Ghost Map* {.quote}
"Most world-historic events - great military battles, political revolutions - are self-consciously historic to the participants living through them. They act knowing that their decisions will be chronicled and dissected for decades or centuries to come. But epidemics create a kind of history from below: they can be world-changing, but the participants are almost inevitably ordinary folk, following their established routines, not thinking for a second about how their actions will be recorded for posterity." (From *The Ghost Map*, p. 32)

But: Is this still true?

# A spatial systems perspective on your problem topic. Continue: >- Thinking through the components of your system. >- Characterizing the relationships between these components. >- Diagramming out these relationships using the approach from the Diez Roux et al. paper. >- Focus on *simplicity*, i.e. if you don't think it needs to be there...it doesn't! ## Useful tools for diagramming systems - [Excalidraw](https://excalidraw.com/) - [Loopy](https://ncase.me/loopy/v1.1/) - Powerpoint/Google slides - Paper/pencil # Next Time {.imgslide} [Miasma vs. Germ Theory](https://notes.epibayes.net/Courses/EPID684/modules/Module+2/Sessions/2.+Miasma+vs.+Germ+Theory) # Making use of evidence across scales is central to this story.
